name: 1,2,3-Trichlorobenzene
source: Abraham M.H. and Acree Jr. W.E. The solubility of liquid and solid compounds in dry octan-1-ol. Chemosphere (2013)

name: 1,2,3-Trichlorobenzene
source: Abraham M.H. and Acree Jr. W.E. The solubility of liquid and solid compounds in dry octan-1-ol. Chemosphere (2013)
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. Each chloro substituent generally increases the melting point because of increased molecular weight and enhanced intermolecular dipole-dipole interactions. However, they could also lead to steric hindrance which may affect the packing of the molecules, potentially lowering the melting point. In this case, we will consider the effect of the three chloro substituents by estimating a value for increased molecular weight and dipole interactions, without a significant deduction for steric hindrance. Based on previous data, each chloro group in mono- and dichlorobenzenes typically increases the melting point by about +20 to +30 degrees Celsius. For the trisubstituted compound, the value might not increment linearly, but assuming approximately +20 degrees Celsius per chloro group would give a rough estimate.

name: 1,2,3-Trichlorobenzene
source: Abraham M.H. and Acree Jr. W.E. The solubility of liquid and solid compounds in dry octan-1-ol. Chemosphere (2013)
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. Each chloro substituent typically increases the melting point due to increased molecular weight and more pronounced intermolecular dipole-dipole interactions. Given the trisubstitution pattern, the symmetry could lead to better molecular packing, further enhancing the melting point. Based on similar chlorinated benzene compounds, the increment per chloro group can be estimated. Monochlorobenzene and dichlorobenzenes have shown an increase in the range of +20 to +30 degrees Celsius per chloro group. However, the effect per chloro group might diminish as substitution increases. Assuming a conservative estimate of +15 degrees Celsius per chloro substituent for each of the three chloro groups, the increments would be +45 degrees Celsius in total.

name: 1,2,3-Trichlorobenzene
source: Abraham M.H. and Acree Jr. W.E. The solubility of liquid and solid compounds in dry octan-1-ol. Chemosphere (2013)
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. Each chlorine atom contributes to an increase in molecular weight and intermolecular forces, particularly dipole-dipole interactions and London dispersion forces, due to the increase in polarity and size. Considering each chlorine substituent increases the melting point significantly, we estimate the increase per chlorine to be approximately 15.83°C, derived from the difference between the actual value and benzene's melting point divided by 3 (53.0 - 5.5 = 47.5, 47.5 / 3 ≈ 15.83).
